Is anyone so sick of dinosaur renderings with their stupid teeth sticking out, no gums? Thank you for drawing gums on your dinosaurs!


This applies to other extinct species too. Teeth depicted as outside of their body, and not kept inside. Covered by gums.

In the worst example, the water predator that had the terrifying saw of teeth...always portrayed sticking out of its mouth...with the back teeth actually pointed into its own jaw from the outside? Always bothered me as a kid. Looked awesome, but fundamentally seemed wrong.

Welp, turns out the saw of teeth was actually inside the mouth, like the throat, used to crush up shelled animals. Very terrifying, actually functional...just not on the outside, looking goofy as heck.

Unfortunately, every single dinosaur with no gums is ruined for me. Every depiction of the poor T-Rex with the goofy over bite, all the top teeth exposed, flush over the bottom gums...literally forcing the bottom gums to be in between the top and bottom jaw...
Meaning, any animal the T-Rex bites onto, the top teeth will close and the bottom teeth will close, and bottom gums will be in the way.
Because there are no top gums & lips to keep the top row of teeth inside, protected, like every other carnivore...
Which also allows a tight seal for any food, too.

NO MORE DINOSAURS WITHOUT LIPS!

I have a minor gripe with the idea of the "unknowable unknown. Rightfully you point out that we can make reasonable assumptions based on the life we have around today, but in the same video that idea is sort of dismissed with the previously mentioned concept.
Even based on the fossils we do have we can make reasonable assumptions of the things that once existed on our planet, even if we don't have evidence for them. We know pterosaurs and ichthyosaurs evolved from terrestrial reptiles, so there had to be an intermediary form which was semi-aquatic in the case of marine reptiles, or gained the ability to perform flight-like locomotion in reference to pterosaurs.

Using spinosaurus as an example of the unknowable is also, in my opinion, just sort of poor decision making. The reason Spinosaurus is in the situation it finds itself in is because of *us*. Because the allies blew up the Munich natural history museum with the holotype still inside (and of course because the nazis forced it to stay there). We've learned a lot more about it, and I think you might've wanted to pick another example.

I hope people realize the significance of Kurzgesagt animating in spinosaurus, or better put, the different visualizations that have emerged of spinosaurus. Spinosaurus was a species of dinosaur so foreign (due to its back sail), people initially couldn't believe what they were finding and assembled its skeleton in classic upright Godzilla fashion. As science progressed, we found out spinosaurus was much larger and fiercer than imagined (due to its teeth) so its design was adapted to a more T rex figure. More recently, scientists believe it to be an aquatic or amphibian species (due to its webbed tail) so currently, it's being represented as a sort of salamander. I explained this truly terribly and skimmed a lot of details, but spinosaurus is such a fascinating creature 😃

1) If you were sent back in time, would you be in the same dimension? I ask because there is no proof that anyone has done so in our past. Unless that proof has been covered up.
2) If there is a cover up of time travelers, then who is going back in time and who is covering it up and for what reasons?
3) If we did act as the guardians of life, should we try to prevent species from evolving so future generations of humans can see what they look like?
4) If we didn't prevent them from evolving but protected their habitats instead, would current animals disappear at a slower rate or faster?
5) Is it possible to preserve images of our current animals to outlast any evidence of their existence from being deleted by time?
6) Is there a possibility of negative consequences for protecting animals?
7) Could a predator learn to hunt us despite modern technology?

They definitely "shrink-wrap" dinosaurs and other creatures when they put flesh on their bones. Many dinosaurs and other ancient creatures may have had far more flesh on them than artists and researchers tend to add to the skeletons. For example, many dinosaurs, when they show what they may have looked like in life, have very visible skull contours, etc. You can even see the shape of the holes in the sides of the skull, under the skin. They probably had far more flesh on their heads than that.

I think there is a gross misunderstanding of reptile behavior based largely around lack of thorough exploration or time spent with them.

Lots of lizards are very cuddly in their own way. I don't see why Dinosaurs couldn't have been the same way without having to be reimagined as giant feather monsters.

To me it feels like people are too eager to shift the paradigm without considering that maybe there was an enormous level of variety and complexity to dinosaur physiology as a whole. We might very well have had both rough scaly and soft feathery versions of the same species all the time.

Edit: Also...preservation is great. Please support genome records... We should preserve the genomes of species in the event we are unable to prevent their extinction and later on have the opportunity to reintroduce them in a better world.

The farther back you look at the dinosaur phylogeny, the more crocodilians should be seen as reference rather than birds. Birds are dinosaurs, but that doesn't make all dinosaurs bird-like, all the way back to the start. Even early birds were more dino-like in some aspects, like actual dentition/beaklessness and perhaps a less endothermic metabolism.

Not saying that the skinny shrink-wrapped lizard version is "correct," but there have been plenty of illustrations around along these lines that "if we reconstructed present-day animals based on bones they'd be weird monsters" that are in a way simply false, those would really be "what non-paleontologist illustrators would perhaps come up with without doing any research on reconstruction." Research that grew over time, the evolution of paleo reconstruction isn't artistic fad, but science-based.

And specifically to dinosaurs, "luckily" crocodiles and birds are indeed generally close to "skinny shrink-wrapped lizards," or plain birds (that don't have so much outer body fat, as image searching for "featheless bird" will show) and so should be dinosaurs, even though there would be indeed some things we'd be missing, if the soft(er) tissues in question aren't preserved or lack any skeletal correlate. Then we can only imagine that there would be some degree of exotic-bird-weirdness sprinkled around to some degree. Although early birds/late bird-like dinos all seem to be roughly "boring," although still with some exceptions, like one with half "flying squirrel" kind of wing, additionally to feathers or proto-feathers, unlike any bird known, live or extinct.

Honestly most non feathered dinosaurs are probably similar to how we portray them. Since their closest living reletives are birds(which are scientifically dinosaurs) and crocadilians we can get a good idea of the fat distribution on their bodies. Color wise the feathered dinosaurs would have the most variety of colors while the non feathered "lizard like" dinosaurs would likely have colors quite similar to most modern lizards and crocadilians. Behavior wise they likely would have acted like modern birds and reptiles with much more simple and instinctual behaviors

I don’t care what anyone says, I’ll stand against the whole entire world, and they can laugh all they want. 

If you take the T-Rex and compare it to a kangaroo...you have a family member. Go look at the skeleton of a kangaroo… Don’t put lizard skin on it, give it fur, a marsupial pouch, long ears, and you have the predecessor to the kangaroo/wallaby. 

Now it will all makes sense.

Short little arms? Go check out a kangaroo. There would be a marsupial pouch for mum and a Joey, and none of this stuff (Long ears, marsupial pouch, fur), would have survived, since it’s all soft tissue. 

Long tail for balancing (when you hop)? Go check out a kangaroo. 

Big strong thighs? Go check out a kangaroo. 

Some jagged teeth...are not just for carnivores (that’s meat eaters to some of you). Now, people can stop making ridiculous claims, when it varies very little from the skeleton of a kangaroo. Short stubby arms… Look around you in nature, and look for things that have the same bone structure. 

It’s like they deliberately have thrown out as a guess every theory ...but what it actually is. 

Anyone finding unusual bones would automatically run down in their mind whether it would have skin, feathers, fur, scales, etc..… They wouldn’t just overlook one of the most common, and in this case, obvious options. Especially one so screamingly, glaringly obvious. 

Go look and compare, give a “T-Rex” the basic external features of a kangaroo and wallaby, the fur, pouch and long ears, and you have a great, great, great, great, great, great, great, great..great and so on... grandparents of them.  

I am the only person I’ve heard of that has made this observation, Surely a “paleontologist“ would notice…or... Maybe not. They’re so busy making up BS, and keeping too many unbiased researchers from examining bones, they either didn’t think of it, or, they are, as usual, deliberately misleading people...

Once you see it, you won’t be able to on see it Once you see it, you won’t be able to un-see it.... I just laugh at people that think ithe T-Tex is a big, scary “dinosaur”. Nope. Just a furry oversized “Roo. But it can punch and kick the hell out of some one or some thing...
More tragic is the ever growing number of people who believe the world is less than 10000 years old and that evolution is not proven. It makes me worry about our future.

I think there would be some mesozoic creatures that would be easier to coexist with than others.

Things we would have trouble coexisting with:
1. Things that are simply TOO big. Titanosaurs and the like would be an issue for small towns because they would probably trample or eat crops but wouldn't be the best farm animals themselves. And even if they don't do that, such a creature would damage human constructs as it trampled through and be a pretty tempting piece of meat and bone for human hunters. Outside Africa, our own gigantic Megafauna have not faired well. And even in Africa, humans still represent a huge threat to them.

2. The unstoppable predators. Coexisting with giant Azhdarchids might be a problem. An animal the size of a giraffe and the weight of a bear, which could fly and swallow people whole, would probably demand a lot of resources to coexist safely with, and after enough people were impaled or swallowed by them, or people got tired of wearing spikey armor when near them to discourage swallowing, it's pretty likely that people would take to exterminating them on sight. The slightly smaller Azhdarchids might fair slightly better because people wouldn't be afraid of ending up in their stomachs, but I doubt anything over 8 or 9 meters would be common within 100 km of a human settlement, and there's a real possibility they'd be driven to extinction.

3. The ones who just eat a cow for breakfast. If you think ranchers don't like wolves, what would they think about animals 200 times that size? 8000 kg predators like T. Rex would become victims of predator culling and overhunting even if it would be fairly easy to stop them from entering human settlements and monitor their activity from vast distances. Stopping them from eating farm animals would be quite a chore, and ranchers probably wouldn't get the memo that there are maybe 20000 Rexes at any given time in all of North America despite their total dominance of the ecosystem. Tyrranosaurs take up a lot of niche space with their different growth stages and if humans start culling any of their growth stages OR its main prey, you can expect their numbers to drop precipitously.

Many people might think that documenting our present is pointless because you could just enjoy the present just as much without ever documenting anything, but (aside from arguments that documenting is something you can enjoy in itself and that it lets you look back on and relive wonderful moments) if it's a tragedy to us now that so much about the prehistoric and prehuman past is lost, then it would probably be just as great a tragedy to future beings to not have information about life in our present, our culture, and our civilization.

We have the technology to preserve information practically forever. If the right dominoes fall, the entire public human record could end up in asteroid sized deep space archives made of glass, shock absorbent materials, and radiation shielding with enough redundancy to last until the heat death of the universe. That entire record could be accessed time and time again by our descendants (both biological and technological) and any alien species that spots it.

And that's just what we can do with the technology we have right now (minus building the archives in space). In the future we might even be able to build super long term radio transmitters and energy sources that can last til heat death too to make some of these archives easier to find

- Dino's existed on a spectrum between reptiles and birds. We know this because they split from repiles, and the decendents we have left are birds.
- We know that birds came from a VERY specific branch of dinos, and thus we can only infer that specific branch from birds.
- We know a very little about specifics aside from bone structure, and thus we simply cant infer much outside of those specifics...

Going any further from what facts we have is irresponsible fake news.

99% of species that have ever lived are all dead and as DNA dissolves completely in 6 million years only a fraction could be resurrected. Success of organic lifeforms is measured in the number of simultanous genera, not in individuals per species. Most vertebrate groups peaked millions of years prior to the existence of humanity, and hominins peaked between 1-2 millions of years ago. All of this means humanity is on its way to extinction or becoming a relic species. Reason being, everything on this planet is controlled by cycles that statistics can confirm and which humanity is incapable of breaking.

This is very interesting and stimulating, however it's essence breaks down to "imagine dinosaurs however you want." This is great in theory but doesn't really answer occam's razor, except in a very round about manner, saying that most dinosaurs should mimic bird behavior. It is most likely that most species will not have useless modifications and it is speculated that most dinosaur traces will never be found. So even if most of the species we do find happen to follow bird like behaviors,  that is not a basis for the amount simply lost, only the ones we can observe and even then it is highly based on speculation. It is however very beautifully put to basically say " we just don't know how they would look, and isn't that quite fascinating"

I remember decades ago when artists first started rendering "colorful" dinosaurs. Books and magazines that featured such depictions usually had a note by them, cautioning the reader that the rendition was "speculative" and that "nobody knows what dinosaurs really looked like." This always struck me as odd, because I grew up as a child with green, brown, and sometimes steely-blue dinosaurs in my books, but nobody ever cautioned at that time that those depictions were likewise "speculative", they were merely "conventional" and had become accepted over time for no particularly good reason except that modern reptiles are the same colors (while ignoring modern reptiles that are strikingly colored and patterned). Such is the conservatism of science, which is not always based on knowledge, but upon what is acceptable at any given time.

I hope that there’s some kind of life after death. One where we have access to a TV that shows us anything in history that we wanted to witness. Or a time machine/platform that lets us travel back in time to spectate whatever we want to learn about.

I’d go back and see the Mongol Empire in action.

Then I’d go to the Edo Tokugawa period in Japan and witness Miyamoto Musashi and all of his battles and epic duels.

Then I’d visit the Vikings and see how they really lived. Then I’d probably spend a lot of time in the Roman Empire and Ancient Greece. Checkout the Library of Alexander. Before each time it was burnt. Then go to Athens and witness democracy in ancient form.

Then right before I go and see the dinosaurs, I’ll stop and checkout the thousands and thousands of years of Ancient Egypt. Like, WAY before Cleopatra’s time. Starting with Ramses II, then Nefertiti, then even further back to I don’t even know what… but I know there was some GREAT kingdoms in Egypt that we lost records of… oh and of course the time the pyramids were being built.

And then I’ll visit other times… like the Dark ages. And the Revolutionary war. And then maybe go back and see how/why Stonehenge was built… and then see Machu Picchu in its glory days.

And then so on and so forth. Until I see everything I wanted to learn about. And once I’m done here. I’ll go checkout other systems and galaxies. See how advanced or primitive they are and how they fair in their own planets. And learn about their cultures and how similar/different they are from us.

I dunno… I think I’m just so excited about this idea, that I’m just talking to the universe at this point… or maybe these are just the ramblings of a crazy person lol

This has got to be one of the best animated Kurzgesagt videos yet. Just starting off, what better introduction to the video than the spiraling beginning of a timeline?

Compared to the previous year's video, Human Era, the difference between the two is astounding, with characters feeling more bouncy and life-like than ever before. That not even starting on the beautifully done perspective stills like at 2:34, the lighting interacting with the lush forest backgrounds (ex. 9:29), the clouds forming at parting at 9:20, or the bird's dance at 8:31; I mean, look at the sun's rays bouncing off the dinosaur at 8:42!

The music is an allusion to the previous Human Era video as well, and the sound design is amazing, especially the little details like the birds knocking on wood at 7:12 and 3:56. I'd recommend anyone to just listen to this original score in its entirety by Epic Mountain, it's so inspiring.
Edit: Just noticed that 5:52 is where the drop is in the score, which has a roar to accompany it, they adapted it into the animation here!

In the not too distant future; maybe this decade; we will know what some dinosaurs looked like by bringing them back to life from DNA. This is being worked on for mammoths. The melting of Antarctica and Greenland will uncover vast riches of species older than mammoths. Unfortunately, our survival is not assured in a runaway warmup.
In any case, large birds that don't fly but run on the ground have been contemporary to us, like the nandu bird, AKA South American ostrich, or rhea, that can grow as tall as a tall man. Argentinian gauchos still practice acts of prowess with boleadoras, a kind of lazo with three weights at the ends of ropes that you'd spin before throwing it. It was used to capture nandu birds while chasing them on horseback. It worked well enough that they hunted the poor birds to near extinction.

I know from the study of bones we know that saurischian dinosaurs like modern birds had air sacks, and as such could absorb and utilize oxygen far more effectively than mammals and our close synapsid relatives.
That is probably one reason why many dinosaur species could reach such big sizes( together with oxygen levels of the time) and why they were so successful, synapsids would have a hard time to compete with a predator who could run without as easily loosing breath, and synapsid predators would have a hard time catching dinosaur prey.
It may even have helped them survive the low oxygen and toxic environment that came late during the Triassic extinction.

Modern birds use such air sacks to fly so effectively in high altitudes and for longer periods of time.

The idea of a cuddly T-Rex makes me laugh. We know from pathologies on their fossil skeletons that they fought each other a LOT, and may even have been cannibals. Some dinosaurs may have been cuddly and relatively peaceful, but T-Rexes were definitely not. They were massive, highly-aggressive killing machines that would have needed to eat a lot of meat to survive. All that said, they were definitely not stupid, and may have even cared for their own young or hunted in packs. And, like other big carnivores today, they were probably not always hunting or fighting one another, even if they definitely were relatively violent. I tend to think of the T-Rex as giving off honey badger vibes. Where does a 7-ton T-Rex sleep? Anywhere it wants to.

I’m not sure this video was has fully researched information.

1: Scientist already claim now that Triceratops is not actually one dinosaur but a multitude of bones put together by mistake.

2: If you believe in evolution, than you should also note how surroundings dictate the colors of a predator. Predators need to blend with the environment. Most plants are green and so most colors in the jungle are as well. A small animal that is quick can get away with flashy colors, not a large animal. Also color blindness was another factor too. If you are colorblind, why would you be a plethora of colors. You’d literally be signaling your presence.

Polar bears appear white because they are in an environment that matches. Lions are yellow and brown because they match their environment. Bears are brown and black to hide and to sneak up on prey. Panthers are black and yellow for the same reason. Crocs and alligators are greenish black to match swamp like conditions. Snakes that are in normally green environments are either green or black. Snakes in a forest or desert are most likely tan or black. Same goes for prey. So when you think ppl got it wrong...which are you referring to? You’re saying that a TREX that is the heighth of an elephant was possibly purple and Orange? Right... They wouldn’t have lasted even 1000 years unless the rest of their prey were retarded. Also, smaller prey tend to be more intelligent due to brain vs size difference which gave them an advantage, if you can say that, with evasion of larger prey. So it’s not just as simple as taking a chicken’s DNA and claiming “look, the color purple might be in here. That means TREXES were purple. Now THAT’s an assumption not based off facts or evolution.

I'm a biologist in training, and I still remember being a kid with a stack of dinosaur books, snake books, and animal books constantly. The wonder that these creatures especially gave me has never left, and lead me to where I am now pursuing a PhD studying biology and how our own bodies work. Y'all's work showcasing science in fun and graphically accurate ways is amazing to me, because what you have demonstrated is how the truth of life on earth is so much more vibrant and interesting than how we teach it in classes.
P.S., I can't wait to see more Immunology videos, as that's my own area of research.

Consider me the kid at the back of the class who was obsessed with dinosaurs and could tell the difference between a Torbosaurus and an Albertasaurus (I'm almost 40 now lol), and I enjoyed the vid, but the feathers evidence is scant and held up by a belief that shouldn't exist in any degree of science. It's grating that even Jurassic World Dominion has jumped onto the T-Rex feathery bandwagon and this needs to stop.

Obviously this is still pure conjecture and fun to consider what may have been, but I will say that fancy colours and dancing dinos are very unlikely.  Those possibilities are based on song birds - mainly tropical song birds.  It's well known that the very complex dancing birds and colourful birds have evolved this way because, quit simply, life is relatively easy for them.  There is an abundance of food all year around and they are not constantly hunted by countless desperate predators (they are prey, but obviously not all that concerned about not being seen).  Meanwhile, if you consider modern apex predators and prey, both tend to be camouflaged rather than colourful - including larger birds (raptors and water foul etc.).  I know the early ideas of dinosaurs were that they were scaly and therefor they used large lizards and crocodilians to model them - and that could very well be inaccurate. Some are so crazy they don’t even believe He ever even existed, even though there’s irrefutable evidence and proof that He did. And others think they’re pretty good people…and think they can earn their way to heaven because of that goodness. The problem is they’re comparing themselves to other people. People who are worse than them of course. And we don’t get to go to heaven because we’re “better than our neighbors.” No sin can enter heaven. None. Period. And bottom line is only those who have repented of their sins…asked Jesus to forgive them for their sins…believed that He died for their sins…and asked Him to save them…will go to heaven. God made heaven. It belongs to Him. And He is the One who gets to decide who can go there, and who can’t. He has made a way for all of us to be able to go to heaven…but many people are so arrogant they think they can do it “there way” and still get there. :( They’re wrong.

To repent means to not only admit you have sinned…but to be truly sorry in your heart for sinning as well. [Not sorry because you got caught…but sorry that you ever did it…there’s a big difference.] Repentance is the key ingredient to salvation that many people overlook. They think they can just pray a prayer…like it’s magic or something…and be saved. But that is not the case. Repentance is a requirement because God only forgives those who are sincerely sorry for what they have done. Just saying “I’m sorry” is not good enough…it’s all about what’s in our hearts.

Think of it this way. Do you have any siblings? Or cousins? Or someone in your life that’s done something to hurt you…that then had your mom or dad or someone tell them to apologize to you for what they did? And then they looked at you and said, “Sorry,” in such a way that it was obvious they were not sorry and were only saying “sorry” because someone in authority over them was making them do it? That is the opposite of “repentance.” It’s only words. It meant nothing because they didn’t mean it and they wouldn’t have even said it if they hadn’t been made to. Now, if you can tell the difference between when someone is truly sorry, and when they’re just saying “words” how much more can God…who knows everything! Our every thought! Our every deed! If we’re not truly sorry…we will not be forgiven. But, if we are truly sorry…and we ask Him to forgive us…He will do it! Immediately. And when we do that…and we believe that He paid the penalty for that sin…and all of our sin…and ask Him to save us…He will do it. Immediately. It’s all about what’s in our heart. Being sincere.

And, if you don’t know Jesus yet, then today you can ask Him to forgive you for your sins…[but only if you mean it]…and you can repent of them…tell Him you don’t want to keep sinning and you need His help to change…and put your faith in what Jesus did for you on the cross…paying your sin debt in full. The choice is yours, the Lord has given you a free will…and He loves you so very much. But He will never force you to love Him in return.

We are, right now, very late in the Biblical “end days”…and the return of Christ for his church prior to the start of the tribulation that will follow is “at the door,” so I hope you’ll consider what God’s word has to say about the days we’re living in and those that are soon coming, because although people can still place their faith in Christ after the rapture they will then lose their lives as a result of their newfound faith as the Antichrist will have no tolerance for those who choose Christ over him. Only 1/3 of those who enter the tribulation will still be alive at the end of those 7 years. The horror of it is, quite simply, incomprehensible. :( If you don’t yet know Christ…please…please don’t wait. Today is the day of salvation. Jesus desires for all to be saved…for none to perish, and we know from His word that is why He has tarried in these end days before coming! But…He will come…soon…because He is the God of His word…and if He said it…He must bring it to pass.

If you’re interested in knowing what’s going on I can tell you with 100% certainty what is happening in our world. Why it’s happening. And what’s coming next.

You see, 2000 years ago [and more] we were told by Daniel, Ezekiel, Isaiah, Matthew, Luke, John, Paul, and Peter among others [inspired by God], what would happen in “our” generation! The “end day” generation…

Why our generation? Because…for reasons only God knows…He himself predetermined that He would fulfill His “end day” prophecies during our lifetime. And so, as He inspired those who loved and served Him to write His word He gave us precise signs and “prophecies” that would be fulfilled in our generation, so that, we would “know that He is God.” In fact, the word of God prophesied a great many details about the days we’re living in. More than most even realize!

One of the most important keys to interpreting Bible prophecy is to remember that it revolves around God…Israel…and Israel’s Messiah…Jesus Christ. I see many making the mistake of trying to “interpret the prophecies” by the “signs”, rather than “interpreting the signs” by the “prophecies”. I didn’t really think about that until I responded to a comment I received from a man who believes we are already in the “tribulation” prophesied in Revelation 6–18. He is making that exact mistake which is terribly heartbreaking. He’s seeing “signs” and then is looking for “prophecies” to match them. In doing so he is misinterpreting Bible prophecy. And, as a result, [in his own words], he’s living in daily torment as he sincerely believes many have been deceived and have unwittingly received the “mark of the beast”, [which seals the eternal fate—to hell— of those who receive it] from Revelation 13 [which has not yet been implemented]. I don’t know if he is telling individuals that they now have no chance of being saved, [referring to those in some countries, who are already using a monetary system that involves them being “scanned” in some way, with a chip in their body, but the implications are horrific if he is!] Telling people that they are now condemned to hell, when in fact they are NOT… and telling them they have received a “mark” that isn’t even yet the “mark” of Revelation 13 is…well…just unimaginable. :(.

En la gripe española de 1918, después de la primera ola de epidemias más leves en la primavera, reapareció en otoño, y más de 50 millones de personas en todo el mundo murieron a causa de la peste.
La gran plaga romana, que comenzó en el siglo VII d.C., se hizo más severa y murieron innumerables personas.

You know, even if t-rex was a cuddly family person. It's rather unlikely that T-rex or any other BIG dinos had feather or fur. Big animals tend to lose these features. Big animals tend to not have fur since it would have a negative effect, they'd get too warm. So unless you're a big hairy mammoth from the deep north, you'll be unlikely to have fur.

Giraffes are tall, not heavy(big).
Giraffes weight about 550-1200 kg, whilst the "small" black rhino wheight about 800-1400 kg.
Oops, that's about the same. Ah right, the giraffe is also 4,6-6,1 m tall compared to the black rhino's measly 1,3-1,8 m. So it's more or less about density, wrong word, but you get my point :)

And considering birds are different from mammals, they don't need to follow the same rules. Thinking of the ostrich, already losing some feathering whilst just being about 2 m and weighting toward 130 kg.

Goosebumps everytime
Why would dinosaur be so different? Where are the social birds?

When imagining what the narrator was saying, the loss of all the information we will never know and knowing that even technology will not help us claw that data back from the abyss, I felt something new. Not to sound over-dramatic but imagining the loss of all that knowledge, I felt very empty and terribly sad. Maybe it is the fact that it is a challenge that humans cannot overcome...or maybe it is the pure beauty, scents, animal calls, mating dances, the moments where a species assures its survival and the moments they were lost forever. The fact we can experience or even just know what they were and ANYTHING about them, the loss of all that knowledge is terrible, and fills me with great sadness.

It did help reaffirm the idea the dream I have of seeing to the survival of as many species as possible. Wonderful areas, cordoned off from human interference but still observable through hi definition cameras. Everything from the largest land animals to the tiniest speaks of coral that desperately struggle against the yawning void of extinction if we don't save them immediately. Maybe climate controlled waters, their own rich ecosystems, so not only do the species survive, but thrive. An animal utopia or garden of Eden, and by using OUR evolutionary gifts, remove many of the lethal hardships that plague them in the wild. Not only will these species live in an actual heaven on Earth for themselves, but we can rid them of diseases, parasites, and speed up the recovery of their major injuries.

Humans have the right to exist and to shape the world in ways we see fit to ensure that we thrive, but we have so much more knowledge than we did a century or two ago when we began our reckless expansions into every possible niche we could find and thrive with the aid of our industrial and technological might. We know what effects we have on the environment and animals that do not have the capacity to understand their peril nor prevent their extinction. And while we rightfully grow our species, cultures, artist masterpieces, and the other hallmarks of culture and civilization, we SHOULD take the initiative to protect those that we share this planet with. We polluted the world while we climbed through the grime and filth of the industrial revolution and the modern era and now that we sit comfortably in the Information era, we have the technology and ability to turn the planet back towards something resembling what it once was. It almost feels like it is a moral obligation, to correct our mistakes and gently guide and improve the lives of species that are unable to do it themselves.

I want to keep as much knowledge away from the unknowable past. I want our species to employ our wonders and might in the defense of those who cannot protect themselves in face of planetary sized threat. Although I wish to do it for other reasons than just the empathy for the animals, we should do it to preserve as much of the history of life as we can. With so many wonderful species catalogued and so many we had no chance of discovering, we should record every scent, sound, color, and more, to be able to confidently say that "These beings lived, they existed, they thrived!". And if we CAN reduce the suffering or misery of species that are being wiped out, why shouldn't we? Let us extend the fruits of our evolutionary struggle back to the world that birthed us along with the other creations that managed to experience life. As far as we know, this planet is the only one we know for sure has life on it, with all the wonders and horrors that life entails, let us do what we can to make sure we can cultivate and nurture life as long as humanly possible. For if we die, and our mistakes continue to plague the planet and its other inhabitants, we might snuff out the only life in the Universe. As unlikely as it is that Earth is the only cradle of life in the Universe, shouldn't we do our best to preserve and help life thrive? If life succumbs to premature death that started by our hands, we MAY wipe out a unique piece of the Universe, one that we do not know how to recreate nor is guaranteed to happen again.

It would be a tragedy for the Universe to exist with all the wonders in our little current slice of time, and be NOTHING around to experience it. Even if it is just an animal that raises its head to the sky because something caught its attention.

I think there's more comparison to mammals being made than is justified: dinosaurs were a version of reptile from which mammals did not descend after all.
Comparing to today's birds has some value, but the size of the animal is going to have a huge impact on behavior as well.
I'd recommend some heavier comparisons against Palaeognathae (Ostrich, Cassowary, Emu, Rhea), Phasianidae (Turkeys, Chickens, Peafowl), Anatidae (Geese and Swans), Accipitriformes (Secretarybird, Eagle, Vulture), and Penguins. Those are frequently ground- or water-based, and more often than not massive or aggressive enough to stand their ground against a larger range and higher weight class of adversaries than a majority of flight-dependent living birds.
Since most dinosaurs didn't have flight and at least most that draw the spotlight did have significant mass and reasons to stand their ground, I would rate those as important behaviors to model from, but without relying on mammalian characteristics unlikely to be shared quite that far away on the evolutionary tree.

As a scientist myself working on preserving modern day animals genomes. It really shucks to see who many going extinct before we can save them for the future when we can PROPERLY clone them and bring them back.

We are trying our best with the knowledge and data sets we have. But honestly its hard work and i dont think were doing enough even. The amount of diversity needed to preserve to actually bring a species back and not have it die out from genetic dead ends is quite a lot. But I guess we can say its better then doing nothing right?

Maybe in the future we will be so advanced with Biology's code as we are with Computer code to fix these issues. Maybe we will be able to rewrite entire genomes with predictive algorithms and AIs that make ours look like toasters. Basically all they will need is a starting blueprint, so the thousands and thousands of unique individuals we are currently preserving will be nice backups but in theory u could just rewrite one individuals genome to act as thousands by changing things all over the genome that would allow for natural reproduction to be stable enough in the wild without our intervention in the lab.
I HOPE SO anyway.

Human Era? Another vain attempt to changing our calendar to something more... secular.
Only slightly less stupid than the (BCE-CE) garbage that doesn't even bother to change the numbers.
Say in the unlikely event that it's adopted, a future question is asked?

-What's year zero?
-When human civilization started.
-We know the exact year that was?
-No... well, not exactly. We tacked 10K years onto an existing calendar cause that's when we thought the first civilization was.
-What existing calendar, and didn't that civilization "start" change by 2K years with more study?
-One centered around Christ, and yes... We found an older civilization a few hundred years after the calendar change.
-Why did we make our calendar center around a moving target?
-Uhhhh...?

The birth and death of Christ is debatable within only a few years and is the MOST historically documented event in human history.
Regardless of anyone's belief (or lack thereof) of his divinity, it's the most rock solid "year zero" we have...
Then why try to make a "new" calendar now (which only grafts onto the current one), if not for the sole purpose of de-Chritifiying the calendar?
And IF that is the reason, then why?
Stop pretending to be "pro-science" when you're really just anti-Christ...

They were pecking at the ground, ostensibly looking for seeds and invertebrates to eat, made way for me enough to walk through the crowd but generally didn't act threatened or even bothered. Busy trying to get themselves their brunch, same as me.

Let's Clone them.

We know even less than we think we do. A lot of the things that are told to the public with confidence are still hotly debated in academic circles. Something as simple as whether or not homo habilis (the first species of homo, named after its supposed use of tools) actually used tools after all, is still debated more than half a century after its discovery. When you don't even know if a species named after its tools actually used tools, you have to admit you don't know much at all. My tutor used to say that evolutionary anthropologists "take a bone and a few rocks and build an entire civilization", where an archaeologist from a more recent era would look at the same finds and declare there was "insufficient evidence to form a meaningful conclusion as to what happened here."

We can make some good educated guesses by juggling physics, chemistry and biology to get every tiny scrap of data from the fragments we find, but we are trying to basically squeeze a camel through the eye of a needle. We don't know that a certain primate species could walk upright, we just think it probably could based on measurements of its ankle bones and comparisons with modern species. We don't know that neanderthals appreciated art, we just think they probably did because they've been found to adorn themselves with raven wings and feathers (they might have just been mimicking humans, or took to wearing them by habit because humans adorned neandertals with them during interaction, in the same way a chimp wears clothes because humans adorn chimps with clothes). In the end we often have to admit we don't know, and can't prove even the things the public have come to think are established facts.

And the soil is an ideal decomposer of organic matter. It destroys the things we need to understand the things we find. Indeed the ground keeps so little of its history, that the further back you go the more you have to just say there is "insufficient evidence to form a meaningful conclusion."

We're stuck on one planet, and have been delving into the secrets of the universe for, realistically, only a few hundred years, yet we know so much.

We know about the beginning of our universe, how stars form, what happens when they collapse, have a good idea what earth looked like billions of years ago, and all number of things that we have no right to know.

We've even got pictures of a black hole, which is just crazy.


As we learn more and dig up more fossils, I wonder what we will find out we have been completely wrong about, and what we've been shockingly accurate about.


We are the first species we know about that can ensure none of it gets forgotten. If we survive, in a million years we may be able to have detailed records of how creatures evolve, how life begins, and so much more

When you consider what the astroid did to the dinosaurs, especially where it hit off the gulf of mexico, one realizes just how much of a hit AND a benefit that was to the fossil record.
On the one hand, billions of living things were encased in ash and dust in an inhospitable environment, which probably preserved a great deal of fossil evidence. On the other hand, the shockwave and heat probably deleted the fossil record down to the bedrock for hundreds of mile around the impact. There were not only living species, but at the time already extinct species in that region that we will just never know about.

What annoyed me very much about Jurassic World is that they didn't take the opportunity to update the dinosaur design. Jurassic Park was kind of on the cutting edge of dinosaur knowledge at the time. They were the place where so many people first learned about the fact that dinosaurs were warm blooded and likely very active animals, not like the slow lumbering lizards they were thought of before 1980.

Jurassic World could've done the same and shown colorfully feathered dinosaurs to the cinemagoing public. They could've even handwaved the change in universe by explaining how the frog DNA made Hammond's first dinosaur set look incorrect. But instead they took the lazy path and made the dinosaurs look exactly the same as in 1994 🙁

Though there is infinite variety in nature, certain patterns--especially behavioral patterns--appear again and again and again. All but a few mammals display some basic, typically mammalian traits like caring for young, grooming, socialization, and so forth. If you look at today's big cats, it's reasonable to assume that sabre-cats in the Paleolithic period almost certainly shared a lot of the same behavioral characteristics. So even though hundreds of millions of years of time (instead of just a few tens of thousands of years) separate birds and dinosaurs, it's not unreasonable to expect dinosaurs to display many of the same behaviors and physical traits of modern birds, including extravagant mating displays, nesting behaviors, diet, and care of young. Natural selection loves to play with details, but I'm always amazed at how few behavioral and structural patterns exist. But, hey, if it works, why screw around with it, right?

I really love your guys videos, they are very informative. However, it would be nice if you presented the belief of evolution and the earth being over several millions of years old as a possibility not fact. There isn’t a way to prove that those theories are a hundred percent accurate at the moment.

For instance I believe what the Bible says about how things came to be and that the earth is around 6,000 years old, if you calculate the ages of people in the Bible. I have no way to prove this a hundred percent despite the fact that I think the evidence we see around us in this world points to it. However, just because I want it to be true doesn’t make it true. Wild imagination cannot and will never give us an accurate picture of how dinosaurs really looked like. Bones can't give a clue at all. Artists know that well yet they like sticking to the pseudoscience tale because it helps them put food on their tables.

Ok so basically, dinosaurs weren't giant lizard-lookalikes, they weren't giant lizard-birds, and they most definitely weren't overly fleshed-out birds with teeth and claws.
(Most)Dinosaurs were somewhat similar to a transitional spot in between the majority of modern birds and reptiles.
Some were feathered, some were scaly, some were smooth, and some were rough.
Adding excessive features that are not confirmed to have been present just makes the reconstruction look like a joke with too much effort.
Adding too little makes the reconstruction look just about as plain as you can get.
Just try to make dinosaurs look like animals that once existed, not like BS movie monsters that would love to make a meal out of you and your friends.
My point is, don't be unoriginal or go crazy with your reconstructions and artworks of dinosaurs! Be creative, but stay within the realms of possibility.
Don't give a sauropod feathers or give a spinosaurus crocodylian osteoderms, be realistic, but in a unique way.

The concept of the "unknown unknown" is so incredibly sad. Thinking about all of the magnificent creatures and environments in this very place we live now, that we will never even know existed...
But at the same time, it can never be understated how equally incredible it is how much we DO know! Time is a linear path that "marches on without any concern for our feelings", yet we have managed to piece together the existence of thousands of creatures dating back to the first signs of life on Earth, and with each passing day we discover more about the things that existed in the time we missed.
It's only by realizing the pain of the unknown unknown that we can truly appreciate the importance of the work the prehistoric community does. While imagining the things we will never know, I can only hope more people will appreciate the things we do.

The unknown unknown:  I am put in mind of the conjecture that a predator like a cheetah was the reason North American Antelope ran so fast-- way faster than any present day predator.  The conjecture came first, the fossil evidence came after.  I've been wondering lately if the same kind of thing can be done with dinosaurs-- using the existing fossil record to show where the empty niches are that would have been filled by *something*.  Not that this would magically conjure the discovery of the fossils, but rather a way give us a bit of a measure of the unknown unknowns and make them a little less unknown unknowns.

Come on Kurzgesagt, we already know T. rex had the largest olfactory capability of any animal to date. We also know the brain of T. rex had huge olfactory lobe and vision area. We also know T. rex had utterly superb stereo vision, with enormous resolution and decent night vision due to the orientation of the eye sockets, and the huge size of the eyes.

Saying T. rex "probably" had good eyesight and good sense of smell is something we'd have said 40 years ago. But today, we know.

For me, the olfactory capability of T. rex is a good indicator he was the ultimate scavenger of carcasses, as well as the ultimate pack hunter, and ultimate solo hunter on land. Terrestrial hunters don't usually rely on smell so much, and it's all about the eyesight. And so having an amazing sense of smell, and being the nastiest thing on the planet, and quite slow as an adult, would tend to indicate T. rex was happy and able to walk long distances to a carcass upwind, and scare off anything else that happened to be dining on it.

T. rex's bite force, and tooth type meant that it could swallow whatever could be bitten off in the mouth, and that included the heavy parts of dinosaurs other animals could not consume. And so if it was a bit late to the party, that was OK.

T. rex may also have even been smart enough to shadow other predators, and simply steal their kills.

3:10 - Now Kurzgesagt, you and I both know Spinosaurus could not possibly have used its tail vertically in water, like a whale.
It is a dinosaur, and so the only possibility is side to side movement for propulsion, like an alligator or a crocodile.
It is the cetaceans and mammals (ONLY!) who use tails in a vertical motion, due to their anatomy.
I am deeply surprised to see such a poorly-informed animation in one of your excellent videos.
It's only a small thing, but quite jarring.

Edit - and at 5:05 you're showing Dunkleosteus doing the same thing, despite it having vertical tail flukes/fins, making it impossible to progress using an up and down motion. Dunkleosteus was a fish, and hence it swam using side-to-side motions.

It goes to show how incredibly much of our distant past that we've learned in the past two decades & how this may further develop in the future. Where once we may have thought there was only the age of the dinosaurs, we now know there were several millennia long ages, each ended by a mass extinction, only for life to radiate out anew from a very few tenacious survivors.

We may not have examples of every species which ever lived, but we do have multiple species (from a remarkable variety of lineages) which show a progression from one form, to another, to another, to the modern variant. Cetaceans, Humans, Equines, Canines, Felines & so many more.

Moreover, we have access to genetic data compiled from tens of thousands of living species - giving us a treasury of developmental code which we can collect to protectively archive, or exploit to revive exinct species (such as the Mammoth & Thylacine). We can protect existing organisms from extinction, as well as parhaps even build new chimeria composed of DNA from utterly disconnected lineages - including, with great responsibility, potentially modifying our own, human genome.

Though the specific methodologies explained in the Jurrassic Park movie series are unfeasable, there's no reason (other than ethical) why we could not build pseudo-dinosaurs (of species which never existed) which may - in many ways - closely ressemble those amazing beasts of ancient history. (Whether we should is another story.)

Paleontologist here, since I was a child I have always been fascinated by dinosaurs, all the books I read, toys I bought, documentaries I watched, etc. EVERYTHING was related to dinosaurs. It seemed incredible to me that millions of years ago such creatures existed. Since that age I knew that my passion was paleontology, I never was a model student, I spent 2 years in a career that I did not like because I could not enter the biology degree, I repeated the university entrance exam and after 7 years since after finishing school, I was able to graduate as a biologist and ended up being a paleontologist. From the books I read as a child with lanky dinosaurs looking like giant lizards until I first collaborated in the excavation of a dinosaur many years have passed, I try my best every day trying to find out how these magnificent creatures looked like. Great video as always, greetings!

regular Kurzgesagt video about space: "space is vast and will continue to exist for a timespan that humans can't even imagine. There is no end to the things you will never know about the future and the vastness of space."
Me: "That's sad. I am sad."
Kurzgesagt: "So about our new video... It's about dinosaurs."
Me: "Uh-oh."
Kurzgesagt: "...and all the things we don't know about them..."
Me: "Oh no."
Kurzgesagt: "...and the things we'll never know about these creatures..."
Me: "OH NO."
Kurzgesagt: "...like how beautiful they were..."
Me: "NO. Nonono... don't do this to me."
Kurzgesagt: "...or how amazingly cute they might have been..."
Me: "Please. Don't."
Kurzgesagt: "...but there is no way we will ever know..."
Me: "Why don't you stop, please stop..."
Kurzgesagt: "...and just consider how many things we don't know that we don't even know about not knowing."
Me: "oh god you're still going..."

Well gee. I guess it's nice knowing that I live in the narrowest part of a hourglass with unfathomably large amounts of knowledge too far away in the future or past for me to ever know. Maybe instead of being sad about never knowing those things, I should really be happy and appreciate the few things that I do experience in this tiny bottleneck of existence. Kinda puts into perspective how lucky we all are to experience things like animals that might become extinct within the decade. All the more reason to do something against it!

If you want to check out more realistic dinosaurs, I would recommend the book “All Yesterdays” by John Conway, C. M. Kosemen and Darren Naish. It’s an art book that has a bunch of dinosaurs depicted like real animals, as well as examples of modern animals with the classic shrink wrap design. There is also “all Your Yesterdays” a free e-book with is full of dino art submitted by fans of the original book.
“All Tomorrows” by CM Koseman is also really good, but it’s about future human evolution.

I am aware this has been said many times before, but after such a stunning video I need to say it again: Kurzgesagt is one of the only channels that constantly sparks an intense sense of curiosity within me and at the same time makes me feel kinda sentimental, although i suspect it's more likely a certain feeling of awe. It mostly has to do with the chosen topics (but also the presentation), many of them actually fall into the unknown unkowns category for in a sense that they are about "obvious" topics and not something super specific, but put the spotlight on an aspect that I never really have thought about before and thus feels almost enlightening. Keep up these videos, they really are something special!
On a side note: it is also pretty cool that the animations and graphics still feel very human and don't have that typical corporate touch, even though Kurzgesagt has been quite a serious and big company for some time now.

Great video. And I can really recommend the youtube channel "cmkoseman" for more stuff about dinosaurs in this direction. And yes, that's the author of "All Tomorrows" with all that weird post-human species. He also co-authored the art book "All Yesterdays" with the paleontologists John Conway and Darren Naish where they basically show what was mentioned in this videos: how dinosaurs were originally depicted as sluggish, slow and often "shrink-wrapped" bony creatures and how it changed. There is also a section where they show really strange interpretations of modern animals. Basically an example how some non-human explorers could misunderstands fossils of modern animals in the future.

I can especially recommend his videos "C. M. Kosemen: What do Dinosaurs and the Cthulhu Mythos Have in Common?" and "Newbies' Guide to Dinosaurs".

The elephant, swan and baboon are from All Todays, a section of another book called All Yesterdays.

For some reason this reminded me a lot of the book “All Yesterdays”, with their depictions of dinosaurs as simply being animals instead of dangerous beasts. I also recognized some All Yesterdays-style illustrations from the book, more specifically their “All Todays” section (murder swan, nightmare baboon and terror elephant). This video is so poignant and beautiful as always, and it’s bound to keep me awake thinking of and trying to imagine all the wild and wonderful and absurd animals we’ll never get to see or experience.

wow, simply marvelous as always! let the existential dread commence.

"Preserving" animals in movies is setting the standard for what it should mean for us to become Human Beings one day (i.e. as that should be) far, far, far too low. For lost animals, it's a wonderful idea, but for existing animals, this amounts to giving up one of the most important fights without a fight.

We should be ambitious enough to keep ever-striving for better, so why not rather start the process of turning Earth into a big nature reserve? We would count for more than the caterpillars if we gave it back; but if we just keep on eating it - like it's some leaf, and we exist to stuff our mouthparts with leaf - then why should anyone care what happens to us? I mean why does it matter any more than that some caterpillars get eaten by birds if we get "eaten" by something (my guess would be something cannibalistic in essence), while continuing as we are, to feed on this leaf?

No, we're not going to achieve this goal in just one lifetime, but at least if we set it, we establish our own value as something worthwhile? If we set the right goals/ direction, we could cease to be quite possibly worthless in ourselves, and start to actually count for something. Wouldn't that be a thing?! In a sense, if we were to give up our current ways to begin working on becoming Truly Important, then we'd actually be Important all along the way. If we actively live out better values, we, ourselves become of some value.

Here's something that we do know about T. rex behavior: they fought. A LOT.
So much so that most if not all complete skulls have bite marks all arround their snouts and jaws, and a couple of them with crown fragments embedded. This means that it was REALLY common for Tyrannosaurs to fight each other by specifically biting their faces.

I've heard one expert claim that this means that they were extremely territorial and hyper aggressive to one another. And it has to be said that apex predators tend to play by these rules, because huge carnivores have big demands that their environment can't always supply, so competition is fierce.

But I think that this also could mean that they were surprisingly social for their size and niche. Definitely not gregarious like lions or even crocodilians (which tend to group in groups and sometimes have complex social behaviors, from what's expected in reptiles anyways). Maybe they gathered seasonally for any number of reasons. Or they managed to coexist, but with regular fighting to establish boundaries without resorting to massive individual territories.

As a bird watcher and someone who has always been fascinated by biology, I love this video! Bird feathers and body’s have adapted for extraordinary uses. That we would never Believe existed if we didn’t see it. Like the comb crested jacanas can carry it’s eggs and chicks under their wings. When when there’s a predator or the water is rising. Sand grouse Live in the desert and their nest are far away from water holes. So when the parents go to git a drink they will soak their breast feathers in the water. The feathers have specialized filaments that retain water and this water is carried to the chicks in the nest. The males of the birds of paradise have extraordinary feathers to attract females. Some species have iridescent feathers, specialized feathers that they can move around and others can change the way their body looks with their feathers and wings. Just imagine what non avian dinosaurs used their feathers for and what adaptations they had. Who knows what strange creatures lived in those jungles millions of years ago.

a few criticisms:
this was a good opportunity to clarify what exactly a dinosaur is: pterosaurs and marine reptiles usually get lumped in with them when thats not the case

you cited cmkosemen's work in the sources when showing the "modern animals reimagined" part, but it was so much of a direct pull from his work that an in-video citation and clarification wouldve been nice

i appreciate the fact that you didnt spend time arguing over the existence of feathers on dinosaurs and instead affirmed it by ignoring the debate - since its very much true

it wouldve also been nice to hear about dinosaur sounds! roars were very unlikely, and its an aspect of dinosaurs in the public eye that is always overlooked

aaaand trex likely didnt possess feathers. in general a bit more detail into skin coverings wouldve been nice. scales, bare skin, flight feathers, downy feathers, etc. its a lot more complex than this video made it out to be.

good video though, its generally satisfying to see this communication given to the public for a group of animals so heavily misunderstood

It's already very mind baffling to realise how condescending we are to our own ancestors.

The way we depict them in textbooks illustrations, modelling in museums… etc. Never have we thought of them (at least in mainstream narratives) as complex minds with profound impotence that had achieved our existence and development as a species today. Let alone other species.

Somehow we take for granted the privileges we enjoy as individuals, and neglect the path that took us here.

It is important to regard the world around us more gratefully and humbly, for every step we take is a continuation of all before and around us, or a step towards extinction of life on earth.

Only the future will know how we were to be remembered. Probably primitive apes that put instant gratification and materials above all else, living in a society built upon slavery.

the segment on hippos, swans, and baboons looking like nightmares came from a book called "all yesterdays" by C.M. Kösemen. he blew up in popularity recently for his book "all tomorrows" depicting human evolution through a Sci-Fi means over the next several millions of years in space. the "all yesterdays" depiction of animals almost "shrink-wrapped" because of the lack of body fat is him justifying his more elaborate designs for dinosaurs in the book by showing just how wrong we could be by using our current animals as an example and a critique of paleo-art from the past and even some artists still around today.

and an unrelated note, or question. the 12000 yeah calendar, hasnt more information come out since your video, showing proof of agriculture as far back as 14,000 and another even 24,000 years ago? i dont mind if the 12k theme stays, as it is almost a brand choice at this point and maybe have a more significant marker than goat herding and clay dolls, but for the argument of human civilization as a whole, it would make since to update it with the continued findings of our history, the same we do for new discovery's in science changing our definitions all so often that can sometimes make people skeptical of the validity of science.
